title: 107_s1604
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Historic Barn Preservation Act of 2001". Congress recognizes the importance of historic barns in the United States, as they are vital to food production and cultural heritage. These barns also provide insight into the country's early agricultural achievements. However, they are at risk of deterioration and demolition. To address this, the United States must protect historic barns for future agricultural use, maintain records on their numbers and conditions, and develop better preservation techniques. To protect historic barns and prevent further loss of these national treasures. The curr_chunk is a section header "SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS." In this Act, a "barn" is defined as a building on a farm for housing animals, storing crops, equipment, or serving an agricultural purpose. A "historic barn" is at least 50 years old, retains its original design, and meets criteria for historic listing. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Agriculture, acting through the Undersecretary of Rural Development. An "eligible applicant" includes a State department of agriculture or a national or State nonprofit organization with expertise in historic barn preservation. The curr_chunk discusses the preservation of historic barns and the involvement of a State historic preservation office. The curr_chunk focuses on the Historic Barn Preservation Program. The Secretary will establish a historic barn preservation program to assist States in listing historic barns, disseminate information, foster educational programs, and conduct research on barn history and best practices for protection. Grants may be provided to eligible applicants for eligible projects. The Secretary will establish a historic barn preservation program to assist States in listing historic barns, disseminate information, foster educational programs, and conduct research on barn history and best practices for protection. Grants may be provided to eligible applicants for projects such as rehabilitating or repairing historic barns, preserving them through fire protection and vandalism prevention systems, and conducting research on techniques for protecting historic barns. An eligible applicant receiving a grant for a historic preservation project must comply with standards set by the Secretary of the Interior. Funding of $25,000,000 is authorized for the period of fiscal years 2002 through 2006 to carry out the Act.
